Big Dave (Eddie Marsan), editor of the Daily Print tabloid, is snubbed by cannabis baron Michael 'Mickey' Pearson (Matthew McConaughey) at a party and hires private investigator Fletcher (Hugh Grant), to investigate Pearson's links to Lord Pressfield, a Royal Duke with a heroin-addicted daughter. Fletcher offers to sell his findings (typed up as a screenplay entitled Bush) to Pearson's right-hand man, Raymond Smith (Charlie Hunnam), for £20 M. Born in poverty in the US, Pearson won a Rhodes Scholarship to Oxford University, where he began selling marijuana to fellow students before dropping out and building his criminal empire by violence. He now plans to sell his business to American billionaire Matthew Berger (Jeremy Strong) for $400 M so he can retire peacefully with his wife, Rosalind (Michelle Dockery). Pearson shows Berger one of the labs where he grows his cannabis under the estates of aristocratic landlords, who need cash for the upkeep of their stately homes. Pearson is later approached by Dry Eye (Henry Golding ), an underboss for Chinese gangster Lord George. Dry Eye offers to buy out Pearson's business, but he refuses. Pearson's lab is then raided by amateur MMA fighters and aspiring YouTubers "The Toddlers" who overpower the lab's guards, steal a van-load of marijuana and upload a rap video of their caper online. The fighters' trainer, known only as Coach (Colin Farrell), orders them to delete the video and is horrified when he discovers that the cannabis belongs to Pearson...

Rotten Tomatoes consensus reads, "It may not win writer-director Guy Ritchie many new converts, but for those already attuned to the filmmaker's brash wavelength, The Gentlemen stands tall." Writing for Entertainment Weekly, Leah Greenblatt rated the film a "B-" and found it to come up short when compared to Ritchie's previous crime films, stating, "The Gentlemen is nothing if not a callback to the Locks of yesteryear, star-stacked and defibrillated with enough juice to jolt a gorilla out of cardiac arrest." Some reviews perceived the film as anti-Semitic, racist, homophobic and sexist on account of its portrayals of characters that fit stereotypes. The Independent described it as "an equal opportunity offender" in its targeting of a multitude of minorities from Jews to East-Asians.

With "The Gentlemen" Guy Ritchie is back at what he does best to be honest (and with that I do mean the two great Sherlock Holmes films he has made as well). Guy Ritchie returns to form with this fast-paced crime thriller. The movie is filled with witty dialogue and excellent performances all the way around. There were rarely any dull moments since all the characters were so fun and colourful, especially when the movie begins to add in elements of blackmail, bribery, deceit, and violence. However, the movie stumbles a bit in its first act. Dialogue comes at you with rapid-fire speed, which can get overwhelming and requires an adjustment period. (But that's most Guy Ritchie crime movies.) You just feel like you're already behind and need to catch up. Once you're adjusted to the narrative style and the movie settles in, everything comes together in an awesome final act.

Overall: Great
Recommended for: Fans of Guy Ritchie films, fans of colourful performances with witty dialogue, or fans of saying Phuc hundreds of times until you get it right. Phuc. Phuc. Phuc.
A Amazing come back by Guy Ritchie,amazing performances,plot,direction,script.

I'm very glad that I watched "The Gentlemen", Guy Ritchie returns to another incredible movie.

The first 40 minutes of the movie were so freakin boring and I was lost, felt like there was confusion or chaos in the story, I couldn't understand anything and there was NOTHING AT ALL that grabbed my attention, but after that, the movie starts to have some events that grabbed my attention this time and they made me excited for what's coming next. 

Loved the "Narration Style" (Idk if that's the perfect word to describe it) of the movie, and how the movie starts off with Fletcher (Played by Hugh Grant) telling a little story but then we realize that it wasn't just a little story it's actually a long story and it's actually the story of the whole movie. 

The action scenes in the movie were very cool but they were very few and they were weak by that I mean I didn't "FEEL" the action and one thing that I really noticed is that "comedy" was taking over "action", but of course the few action scenes were so cool and I really enjoyed them. 

Really loved the "little" plot twists that were in the movie and unfortunately, I can't talk about them or I'll spoil everything. 

The characters were LIT and that's thanks to the cast of course. Coach (Played by Collin Farrell) was my favorite character in the whole movie, Ray (played by Charlie Hunnam) was amazing, Fletcher (played by Hugh Grant) was also amazing, the charisma of each character is the thing that really saved the long conversations or maybe the whole movie, to be honest, and without it, these conversations would've been boring as hell and the movie was gonna be dead.

Really loved the production design that really suited the environment and the characters, also the custom designs were pretty cool and fancy exactly like they should be. 

Now for Mickey Pearson (Played by Matthew McConaughey ), I wish if we could have seen him more in the movie, felt like he didn't have much of a role or something, he was just the "BOSS" that has his guys to do everything for him and to be honest it makes sense he's the guy who built the highly profitable marijuana empire so of course, he's just gonna have his guys do everything for him, they even call him "BOSS" the whole movie, but I still wanted to see more of Mickey Pearson or to be specific, I wanted to see more of Matthew McConaughey. 

Although all the characters in the movie were "BAD CHARACTERS", we still really loved them that's a thing that I loved about the movie. 
Felt like there were some characters that weren't even important in the whole movie or they didn't have much impact in the story and one of them is: Dry Eye (Played by Henry Golding), although his acting was okay, his character was a waste of time.

The Gentlemen is a very funny and interesting movie, filled with a bit of action that you'll enjoy, really recommend this fun movie.

A mess... I'm not sure if it's even worth it to nitpick at every single flaw. I didn't know it was possible for a movie to be both complicated and lazy at the same time. On the positive side, it never bored me at any point. The pacing was really good. I watched it in one sitting, which I can't say for truly terrible films. The photography was also great. That is where my compliments end. Henry Golding's character was written in such a racist manner. A lot of the dialogue was trying too hard to be deep and witty & ended up sounding corny. So many threads and characters are thrown at you quickly, but I eventually got it all straightened out by 60% through the movie. The overuse of f-bombs and the c-slur is an example of the laziness in this script. Jeremy Strong's acting was weak here. It ends by alluding to a sequel... a sequel?! No, baby, no. You won't get my attention again.

This movie is good. It is not great, but it is a solid film. It is about a drug kingpin that is trying to sell his business and all of the back-stabbing that goes along with it. It is interesting to watch, but sometimes it moves at a much slower pace than it should. There is some witty dialogue and the acting is great. There is a feeling of style over substance though which is a bit of a hinderance. There is some dark humor scattered throughout its runtime which livens it up from its oftentime very serious crime world. The movie is told mainly by Hugh Grant's character, Fletcher. He followed this crime story and wrote a screenplay about it and wants to use it as blackmail against the drug lords. He explains in ferevent detail what the story entails, so there is a lot of exposition in this story and a lot of cutting away from seeing the story to watching Fletcher explain what is happening. At the beginning it seemed like a fun little gimmick, but by the mid-way point of the movie it just got a bit annoying. It is kind of like how "The Princess Bride" is done but with less charm. Guy Ritchie is fairly known in the directing world for having very stylish movies, like the "Sherlock Holmes" movies. This is movie has all the style and slickness we have come to expect from Ritchie, but there is just a lack of connectivity between the story and the audience. However, this movie is fun and will keep you entertained with its several moving pieces. I do think it does a really good job of tying everything together at the end, and I thought its ending was fairly satisfying. The meta-appeal of it being a screenplay is a bit too meta for my taste for this type of movie, but it does add a bit of flare to it. This movie has a lot of vulgar language, and I think it would have benefited if it toned down the profanity a bit. I enjoyed this movie though, and I think it is worth a watch. Overall, I give this movie a 7.5/10.

Guy Ritchie sees himself in rare form for his latest crime comedy The Gentlemen (2020). I have to immediately mention that Ritchie's script writing is incredible. He writes an intricate crime narrative with multiple drug lords going at each other's industry, but he shocks you with twists and turns you will not see coming. Guy Ritchie takes his 1990's grit and edge and refines it with contemporary style, references, music, and language for The Gentlemen. I really enjoyed his abundance of English slang that only younger audience members would catch. The Gentlemen is Guy Ritchie going full British director unapologetically and I love that.

His attention to detail in his written setups is as impressive as James Herbert and Paul Machliss' slick editing that keeps The Gentlemen to a tight 113 minutes. Ritchie writes his heroes and villains as all realistically vile, racist, greedy, violent, selfish, and repulsive monsters in his unique voice. His direction has never been more thoughtful and refined as Ritchie does not waste a shot. Alan Stewart's cinematography is gorgeous with wide shots of sets ornately decorated by Sarah Whittle and styled by Gemma Jackson with a modern production design befitting a Tom Ford film.

Christopher Benstead's score is subtle, then suddenly boisterous and matches The Gentlemen's mature tone. Michael Wilkensen's costumes look like he was dressing actors for a James Bond film. In fact, The Gentlemen is very much James Bond meets Snatch. Guy Ritchie's use of rock, rap, and random other genres is very refreshing to hear in a contemporary film. I'm so glad that Guy Ritchie did not tone down his charming, English style.

The Gentlemen features a magnificent cast of talented actors and actresses delivering riveting character actor performances. Matthew McConaughey is phenomenal in a unique turn as a methodical, careful drug lord called Mickey Pearson. Instead of the eternal stoner like in The Beach Bum or Dazed and Confused, McConaughey brings menace and leadership as the focal point of The Gentlemen. Charlie Hunnam is the standout of The Gentlemen as McConaughey's right hand man Raymond. He's a far cry from his usual bruiser hothead characters, instead Hunnam plays Raymond as a cautious sidekick with OCD and subtle observant expressions.

Hugh Grant has to be mentioned as the sleazy, self-serving reporter Fletcher as his everyman accent is hilarious. His narration is riveting because of how strange and particular Grant goes for in this unusual role that you'll just have to see for yourself. Eddie Marsan has a great supporting role as the insecure media man Big Dave. Chidi Ajufo is great as Charlie Hunnam's henchman Bunny.

Henry Golding sheds his nice guy romantic leading persona as the vicious and violent crime lord Dry Eye. Michelle Dockery is lovely as McConaughey's wife Rosalind with a fun Cockney accent instead of her usual posh accent. Jeremy Strong is funny as Cannabis Kingpin Matthew with his quiet jabs and intense presence. Colin Farrell delivers a killer fighter role as Coach. He's hilarious and caring at once. Farrell is so exciting to see act in dramatic roles and funny in comedic roles. Everyone brought their best for Guy Ritchie and it shows.

In all, The Gentlemen is a crime film that will age well as it's so technical that you'll always be able to catch something new upon revisiting it.

Just awesome! This is Guy Ritchie back to classic form. Oh how I missed movies like this from this guy. A great ensemble cast in a hilarious, quirky crime caper. Oh boy, I hope he keeps on this path.
Another brilliant film from Guy Ritchie. Stellar cast, well written, directed and great dialogue.

Less than the sum of its parts; cool action scenes, decent performances, interesting characterisations and bits of witty dialogue here and there, but the structure is deeply flawed and messy, and the plot is too convoluted for its own good -- I guess Ritchie thought his film is way smarter than it really is.

What really bogged this movie down for me though is Ritchie's persistence to veer away from his early style which he presumably, to some degree, returned to here. I get that he wanted to return to form without making yet another version of Snatch and Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels (both of which I liked, especially the former), but I'm quite not sure whether most of the choices he made here in order to render the film a refreshing feel worked together. Regardless, The Gentlemen is a good fun with enough clever touches to satisfy Ritchie's fans.

For those exposed to Guy Ritchie's early work (‘Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels', ‘Snatch') before anything else and found themselves missing that gritty, stripped-back, typically British flair that defined his films, ‘The Gentlemen' is closer to that than he's gotten in years after making a number of big, Hollywood-polished blockbusters.

It's got gangsters; it's got the London setting complete with copious amounts of swearing; it's got the twisty plot and jumping back and forth in time; it's got the vulgar comedy that often involves violence; and it's got a great cast to go with it. What stops this from being up there with the best of his work is the distinct lack of interesting, colourful and unusual characters (save Hugh Grant who steal's the spotlight with his role) which means that the aforementioned cast often goes to waste. 

Nevertheless, it's still pretty fun; I just hope that if there's to be a sequel, Ritchie manages to find a way to infuse a bigger dose of that original flavour that packs more of a wallop.

If you can afford to build the infrastructure for 12 illegal underground pot farms with enough shielding to prevent helicopters from detecting all the florescent lighting from above then they can surely afford a simple key lock on the "front" door. Lol Other than that one issue this is your typical Guy Ritchie movie, but if you are looking for a more believable story try watching Wrath Of Man.

This is a massive redemption from Aladdin 2019 ( clearly a paycheck movie ). The film 🎞 is a great throwback to his new old work such as but not limited to (Lock, Stock, and Two Smoking Barrels, Snatch, RocknRolla, and Sherlock Holmes). The latter of which I could best describe as Gritty British Crime Dark Comedies as a very particular genre to jolly ole England 🏴󠁧󠁢󠁥󠁮󠁧󠁿 and Director Guy Richie. Do I even need to say all the performances are great, the moment I saw the cast list and what kind of movie 🍿 this is, I knew everyone was going to be a tone of fun to watch. Especially Hugh Grant, Colin Farrell, and Mathew McConaughey playing up caricatures and having so much fun in their roles. The few things holding it back though is some scenes do feel like they drag on for a while too long, and are not as funny as his previous films. Not to say there weren't any laugh out loud moments there were hilariously dark moments hence the blend of different genres and unlike Knives🔪Out it has a much more likable charm to it, doesn't feel forced to add in any reference to the current political climate (thank GOD). Editing added funny visuals and transitions between scenes. Along with the cinematography adding visual flair to who the characters and the dynamic between them. Overall while not as his early work like Lock, Stock or Snatch its definitely the best of his more recent work and I hope it does well enough at the box office to allow him to do more projects like this and allow for more creative freedom and I give the movie 🎥 an 8.1/10.

In this new Guy Ritchie film, Michael (Matthew McConaughey) has created a multimillion-pound marijuana growing and selling operation in London. When he decides to sell the business, there are several characters who try to figure out ways to take the business from him. This is a weird movie. The dialogue is for the most part really corny and bad; I am not quite sure if it was intended that way (I think it was), but in many cases,  it isn't funny. To Ritchie's credit, when his brand of craziness works, it is really funny. The only saving grace for me is Hugh Grant's performance – he is hilarious as a paparazzi-type character who has his own objectives related to the marijuana business. Overall, I just never could get into it. I give it a thumbs up because of Grant's performance; I appreciated Ritchie's earliest ventures, Lock Stock and Two Smoking Barrels, and Snatch, much more than this one

No one is asking him to duplicate his Lock, Stock supernova success. No one is really asking for any of this at all. And while it's understandable if the writer-director wants to get back to basics — to prove that the shock of the new may be gone, but the chops and cheekiness remain — there's the sense that maybe moving on was the smarter move all along.

SPOILERS FOLLOW, HERE FOLLOW SPOILERS:

So, I've warned you TWICE and don't want to hear any boo-boo-hooing from the malchicks and devotchkas about spilling the beans and sausages.  Proceed at your own risk, my Dear Readers, as Your Friend and Humble Narrator spins his yarn.   You'll notice I've appropriated some content from something else.  A CLOCKWORK ORANGE. That is intentional, I assure you, the reason for which shall be ultimately revealed to those few who finish this tale.

This is an excellent movie, with an asterisk.  The asterisk qualifies my feelings about it as you shall see.  Enough dancing; I'm making my move.

The writing sparkles with wit and nuance in this complex, multi-layered film that somehow feels like THE BIG SHORT, while being nothing like it in story at all.  You'll delight at the British, Irish, and Scottish slang that abounds here.  The clever witticisms and charming local color.  Breaking the fourth wall on a meta-level.  The extensive use of a narrator who weaves a story told as a film plot that delivers most of the exposition.  It all works. 

The acting is first rate, as one would expect.  The filthy and slippery lead character and narrator Fletcher, captured beautifully by Hugh Grant, is an unctuous homosexual blackmailing curr.  The performance is a revelation.  Charlie Hunnam, whom I've never really noticed much before, is also excellent.  If possible, it's Colin Farrell who steals the show from the fine performance of Matthew McConaughey.  These characters swim in personality, each their own.  So, no problem there.

The story is problematic as it recycles LOCK, STOCK, AND TWO SMOKING BARRELS, a fan favorite I find in every way inferior to SNATCH.  Although this film has elements of both, it leans well towards the former.  It's no secret I do not like drug content, which is very much the background here.  Nonetheless, still not the problem.

The problem is the borrowing and recycling herein.  I suspect there may be legal action in future.  Yes, Ritchie borrows heavily from his own work.  The trademark car crash.  Boxing and fighting.  The pub settings and Houses of Lords.  The Marijuana manufacturing.  Not my thing. Yet, still not the problem. 

This film very obviously "borrows" from two things it shouldn't, unless there were arrangements made.  The first is Black Mirror 1:1, my least favorite episode, which grotesquely involves a blackmail plot involving unnatural acts between a man and a pig.  It's very unpleasant, and this film makes it funnier and less onerous by implying more and showing less.  But it's still a direct replay of the shocking 2011 production, if only in passing in one scene.  It's flagrant.  That's a problem.

Also problematic is the borrowing from SE7EN of the pound of flesh theme of the Sin of Greed scene.  Almost no variation at all.  Once again instantly identifiable and quite flagrant. 

Future legal issues or no, I was very disappointed in these "borrowings".  They're essentially verbatim and so obvious that my wife, not a fan of such things, immediately identified both on her own, without help, on first viewing.

You'll recall the TWELVE MONKEYS lawsuit and theft of the conceptual design of the inquisition chair and inquiring eyeball machine Bruce Willis was subjected to.  The production approached the artist for licensing.  They were given a price, didn't pay it, and used the set piece anyway.  It cost them millions in a resounding negative verdict.  For stealing a set piece for a single scene.  This was more than that. 

These things may not bother most, but they certainly bother me.  An entertaining film with an asterisk for some glaringly obvious problems.  ***. 5/*****.  74/84.
I really love the dramatic setting. Who will come out on top? Really great in my opinion.

Midway upon the journey of a criminal life.

Not always is going forward a necessary improvement. 
This is proved by Guy Ritchie's latest movie, The Gentlemen, a brilliant coming back of the British director, after the detours from his original imprint and trade mark represented by Aladdin (2019), King Arthur (2017) and in a way also The Man From U.N.C.L.E. (2015), as well as the diptych of Sherlock Holmes, to his origins, those that brought him success and a distinctive narrative and filmic style centered around the London criminal underworld.
Nobody really believes that the British criminal gangs medley so gracefully cruelty and greed with the irresistibly cool, debonair attitude that denote Guy Ritchie's characters, but it is honestly pleasant to find them again on the screen, it is a like meeting after a long time a distant relative, a bit dissolute but in the end loved and, to a certain extent, even secretly envied without admitting it.

The American Mickey Pearson, well played by Matthew McConaughey, crossed the Atlantic to study at Oxford but soon became a drug kingpin, aptly able to benefit from his contacts with the needy British aristocracy to build a commercial empire for the illegal production and distribution of marijuana on a national scale.
Midway upon the journey of his criminal life and happily married to true cockney Rosalinde, he decides to transit to legality and offers to sell all his activities to Jewish entrepreneur Matthew, constantly body-guarded by former Mossad agents.
This decision sparks a far-reaching series of effects and subplots that bring onboard various secondary characters, amongst whom Colin Farrell steals the show, that are craftily kept together for the viewers by Fletcher, an investigative journalist working for a tabloid which chief editor holds a grudge against Pearson. Fletcher intends to monetise through blackmail the information he has collected, and those he has only guessed to fill the gaps of what he still doesn't know, and contacts Pearson's top man, Raymond, excellently played by a Charlie Hunnam much more at ease here than as King Arthur. Hugh Grant as Fletcher is in sterling form here, lending an unusual and idiosyncratic charm to a role that deviates, and we should say thankfully and eventually, from the expected characters he has built his successful career on.

Mixing his trademark brisk and sparkling dialogues, Tarantino-like yet unmistakably made in Ritchie, with a crafted and expected British-ness of costumes and settings and a pleasant, defining yet not intrusive soundtrack, The Gentlemen is, to put it simply, a very good movie that gives the viewers what is expected of Guy Ritchie, sprinkling cinephile quotes (Coppola's The Conversation, old film reels) and well-integrated self-quotes (Snatch's pigs and poster of The Man from U.N.C.L.E. amongst others) on an excellent camerawork servicing a tight narrative pace whose thread, mainly for Fletcher's catchy story-telling, is never lost during the film and until its, partially unexpected, ending. 

A step back,  but towards the quality if his directorial origins, for Guy Ritchie, The Gentlemen will not be remembered for its innovations but it is a solid, well-written, directed and acted, genre movie.
Nowadays, not too bad!

There's plenty on offer to have fun with here; the vibe of the film, the characterisation of its very appealing ensemble cast, its playful and metaphorical manner of speech, and even its premise. I certainly enjoyed all of these aspects in The Gentlemen, but do understand its heavy use of strong coarse language and other offensive remarks made throughout has diminished or reduced that enjoyment.
Not his best but still a very entertaining venture.

Of box office disappointments, weird decision-making, and general mediocrity, the 2010s were a rough decade for Guy Ritchie—excluding the sweet, sweet Sherlock Homes: A Game of Shadows, that is. I don't know, maybe The Man from U.N.C.L.E. wasn't the worst thing ever. Aladdin wasn't very Ritchie-y, though. And I'll shamefully admit I'm still waiting to see the apparent insanity that is Legend of the Sword. Anyway, Ritchie's back to his mobster movie roots with The Gentlemen, and oy oy, I'm chuffed to say it is as entertaining and stylish as it is faffingly British. Indeed, a jammy return to form for the bloke, biscuits and tea, and all that.

The Gentlemen follows Matthew McConaughey as Mickey Pearson, an American living a life of excess and splendor in the UK thanks to his enormously successful underground marijuana empire. Though ready to put up the mantle, a smarmy blackmailer and rival criminal plots pop up, threatening to ruin his retirement. While Mickey goes around town finalizing his business settlements, his right-hand man, Raymond (Charlie Hunnam) tails the conspiracies revolving around his boss' friends and enemies.

With all his coined Texan smoothness mixed with an imposing gangster presence, McConaughey's as great as ever as Mickey, and I especially dug Hunnam's surprisingly pleasant performance as his chivalrous, kindly goon, Raymond. The true lifeblood of the film, Hugh Grant also gets tons to do with an electrically eccentric performance hammed up to eleven, and Collin Farrell squeezes in a neat little supporting part in there as well.

Sadly, Michelle Dockery and Henry Golding get screwed by significantly weaker writing. Golding's character is particularly unpleasant with potentially racist undertones that carry through the rest of his sometimes fun, more often off-putting subplot. They're fairly minor roles in the scope of it all, though, and Dockery at least manages to own her role well enough.

But everything I've written greatly undersells the movie. A unique non-linear framing device unravels the film with sidebars and digressions ripe for Ritchie's flair and comedic pickings, and, as expected, the story explodes with personality at every turn. Do you like rapping, acrobatic martial artist YouTuber gangs? Fancy fancy dudes committing dapper crimes?  Are you just looking for a really good time overall? The Gentlemen's got you covered, baby.

The Gentlemen is a highly entertaining film from the one and only Guy Ritchie. The ensemble cast is all great. Guy Richie has been a director that hasn't always blown me away in the past. I've been amused by his outings with Sherlock Holmes and quite enjoyed The Man from U.N.C.L.E., but I wasn't even all that impressed by his fan favourites, like Snatch. For myself, I see that's he's now on a nice little streak. I really enjoyed his live-action remake of Aladdin and I think The Gentlemen may be my favourite film he has ever done. Although it does get a little self-indulgent at times, here's why I believe The Gentlemen may impress you, even though you may need to have an acquired taste for it. 

The Gentlemen tells the story of Michael Pearson (Matthew McConaughey), a man who wishes to sell off his Marijuana empire in order to escape from the crimes he has committed. This leads to a lot of blackmailing and mistakes, which then leads to death and chaos. However, at its core, this film is about Fletcher (Hugh Grant), a man who is trying to make this story into a feature film. This element was probably my favourite portion, as it tied current events into past events, which made for an interesting experience. Sadly, that formula became a little self-indulgent by the final act.

As I mentioned, Guy Richie, who directed this film, has a very unique style. To get the negative out of the way first, without ruining anything for viewers, there is a scene towards the end of the movie that breaks the fourth wall in ways I haven't seen in a while. That particular scene left a bad taste in my mouth, but I enjoyed the rest of the movie too much to let that be a huge detractor. From his witty/snappy dialogue to his hilarious choices of the way certain characters speak, he has certainly not lost touch with the types of movies he likes to make. For myself, this one just happened to work for me, more than any of his previous original work.

From Matthew McConaughey to Charlie Hunnam (who is fantastic in this role), Colin Ferrell to Henry Golding, and the rest of the endless talent, The Gentlemen is an embarrassment of riches when it comes to the talent on-screen. I was actually worried throughout the first 20 to 30 minutes that it felt a little messy and that these actors wouldn't have many ways to shine, but I was wrong. This movie finds its footing by the end of the first act and never lets up. I was thoroughly impressed by the acting, screenplay, and overall editing throughout the film, that my complaints never ruined my enjoyment. 

In the end, The Gentlemen isn't a perfect movie and Guy Richie definitely pats himself on the back a little too often this time, but I would be lying if I didn't say I had an absolute blast. The dialogue came a mile-a-minute and it was either important to the story, clever for the sake of being clever, or simply hilarious, and I just ate that aspect up. The quick style of this movie won't be for everyone, but if you happen to enjoy that sort of thing, then you may just love this movie. I like that style when it's done well and it really worked for me here. The Gentlemen is a fun time and I recommend checking it out.

Guy Ritchie is back! The Gentleman is another great story by one of my favorite directors. Gangster comedy is Guy Ritchie's wheelhouse and the proof is in the movie.

Guy Richie doesn't 'show' us this tale, he tells us, he editorializes the story, which in and of itself, is not a bad vehicle for a story - especially one as well realized as the one we are told in The Gentleman. Unfortunately, it is a weaker vehicle for carrying a tale to the viewer. It takes much greater control of the craft of film making to 'show' us the story and let us come to the conclusions that the storyteller is hoping to lead us to. 
This is the only weakness in this movie, because of all of its moving parts, the director may have found it the only viable technique to encompass all of the tales convolutions. This tale has many intricate dimensions and so has a lot of ground to cover in its limited time, so its director may have found this way of taking the viewer along for the ride as his only recourse.
Other than that, this movie's story is good and enjoyable. I found myself glued to it from the hook in the opening. The ensemble cast is superb and the acting is A list quality, so maybe I should have given it four stars, but won't due to the nature of the story being told - it is not a world shaker. It is about a minor league player on the world stage of life's underbelly - the noble savage, if you will. There are many like him in the world whose stock and trade have come of age, the weed industry. His one act of nobility is that his trade doesn't kill people - but his business does. He'll not garner any sympathies or respect from this writer.
It's a gangster movie, and a good one, but not an earth-shaking one, just another little man who would be king and does become so, in the end, through rather clever means and by staying one step ahead of the other big fish in this otherwise small English pond. I would recommend it's viewing if you enjoy Scorsese's content without the Scorsese style of 'showing' you the story rather than narrating it to you. 

That's my rating, and I'm sticking to it.

Another great Guy Ritchie flick

Guy Ritchie's career has had its ups and downs, and while The Gentlemen might not be his greatest film, it's certainly the best he's done in a while. It's a return to the gangster black comedy that made him famous in the first place, and he relishes in the chance to do it all again. Full of comically over the top dialogue, witty verbal exchanges, bursts of violence and foul-mouthed characters in a variety of attire, its much like a Tarantino film, only not as long-winded. The plot sounds surprisingly complex, but Ritchie keeps things well paced, and as such you are never overwhelmed by the information presented, so its surprisingly easy to digest. It does often tread on ground that Ritchie has covered before, but what keeps you invested are the characters and their banter. Colin Farrell is hilarious as always, Hugh Grant is delightfully slimy, Matthew McConaughey is a lot of fun as the top dog, trying his best to sound convincing with the British wordplay and mostly succeeding. As some have remarked, those who aren't already Ritchie fans will likely be put off by The Gentlemen, whether by its vulgarity and brashness or its offbeat nature, but for his sizeable fanbase, it's another riotous good time that combines savage comedy with even more savage drama.

"All in all, The Gentlemen is another hit for Guy Ritchie, and it might even be his best movie yet. With one of the most complex screenplays in a while, the phenomenal cast elevates this crime-thriller into one of the best films of 2020, so far. Matthew McConaughey, Charlie Hunnam, Hugh Grant, and Colin Farrell stand out, but every actor delivers excellent performances. Extremely funny and captivating storytelling through Grant's narration, which ironic or not, it's both the best and worst component of the movie. When used in excess, it can be a bit bothersome and lengthy, but for most of the runtime, this alternative to substantial exposition works brilliantly. Interesting characters, intriguing mystery, and hilarious bits of comedy make this feature very entertaining. Technically, great editing keeps a well-paced flow, but it's Ritchie's layered narrative that steals the show."

Where have you been, Guy?  So this is about an American entrepreneur in London (Matthew McConaughey).  He's looking to retire and sell his lucrative marijuana empire, but when everybody surrounding him has their own elaborate scheme, this isn't going to be easy.  Now I have always held Guy Ritchie in high regard even though it has been over a full decade since he directed a movie that I liked more than I didn't.  I adore Snatch to the point that I consider it to be in my top 10 movies of all time, so I feel obligated to always give him the benefit of the doubt.  I am very pleased to report that this is the movie I've been wanting from him for years and years.  Now while Matthew McConaughey may be front and center with top billing, I wouldn't call him the star of this.  He is well and good in this, don't get me wrong, but Hugh Grant steals the show in this as this charismatic and salacious private investigator.  He is so cheeky and having fun with the part that whenever he is on screen, you can't wait to hear what he is going to say next.  Everybody in this gives quality performances.  Sure, they're all given that macho tough-guy cockney dialogue which we have come to expect from a Guy Ritchie gangster flick, but everybody is committed to the characters and knows how to land a joke.  In fact, the characters are so well rounded and rich that I feel like it makes up for some of the shortcomings in the story.  The movie utilizes the unreliable narrator technique, usually to comedic effect, but it does sometimes make you work to keep up with various story points.  The forward motion of the plot does get muddled at a number of points, but the dialogue is so well written that I was able to forgive it and look past it.  I don't know if the expectation of not having loved a Guy Ritchie movie in ten years had anything to do with it, but I had a great time with this from start to finish.  It moves fast with well-timed jokes, and nobody phones it in, so there isn't really a weak link.  I would happily watch this again, and 2020 is already shaping up to be one of the strongest starts of the year we've gotten in cinema in quite a long time.  I give The Gentlemen an enthusiastic recommendation.

The Gentlemen took some time to get me on board, because it didn’t settle into the proper tone right away. Bouncing back and forth between the super-serious world of Matthew McConaughey’s drug dealing, and the goofy story-telling of Hugh Grant was odd. I wasn’t even chuckling all that much in any of the opening scenes, despite amazing performances from all the cast. However, there was a point where the movie turned a corner and I let out my first audible laugh. Somewhere along the way I found the humor in the serious stuff, and I was totally on board with the blend of styles, and the story that continuously bounced around in time. Once the floodgates were open, I was laughing a ton at all the crazy antics. It’s been a long time since I last watched a Guy Ritchie film, so I forgot how he structures his stories, and how he writes comedy. As with most of Ritchie’s early films, the profanity flies fast and loose in The Gentlemen. I can’t say I enjoyed how freely they threw around the four-letter words, but I was desensitized to it after a short time. The film doesn’t quite flow as smoothly as I’d like either, because Ritchie wants to constantly play with non-linear story-telling. There are moments where he will leave out a detail in a scene and, even though we could probably fill in the gap ourselves, he feels the need to bounce back and show it. Unless you’re going to shock the audience with a surprise reveal, this kind of editing is style over substance. However, I loved the fact that most of the movie is told in the format of a movie pitch, and even has mistakes because Hugh Grant’s character doesn’t know all the details. There were so many fun moments in The Gentlemen, and it had laughs to spare. While it pales in comparison to Snatch, it is still an enjoyable time at the movies.

So, The Gentlemen. First of all--I had absolutely no idea what this film was all about--none. It was Wednesday--movie night. My wife wanted to see Harley Quinn, but, since it was my turn to pick, we saw this one instead. The film is presented in typical Guy Ritchie style, very interrogative, just barely but not quite breaking the 4th wall. I'm pretty sure Matthew M. has made a career of playing characters like this: a not--quite-legit guy operating outside the law and locking horns with other not-quite-legit guys. Lots of colorful characters pop up as the film progresses. I'm pretty sure Hugh Grant's character is gay--not sure, but I think so. Collin Farrell's eyebrows, and his hideous track suit, ought to have been given a screen credit of their own. All in all, I was pleasantly surprised by this slick little crime thriller. Some scenes, like the one in the crackhead's apartment, go on for way to long, and, if I'm counting correctly, the film had not one, not two, but three endings before it finally did end.

I feel like criticism was unfairly harsh on this, most of which seemed to be saying that this movie was a generic run of the same story you’ve seen many times before. Formulaic, predictable, etc. It kind of felt like that was the point, to me, because the entire movie was this guy reading his screenplay adaption of what actually happened. And I didn't think it felt trite or anything, it had a strong identity to it. It felt, to me at least, that it was able to draw very intentionally from a lot of archetypes of British action classics without feeling a cheap copycat. It’s odd to me that a movie like Knives Out, which follows much of the same conventions, is praised for drawing from obvious influences while subverting expectations, but this is panned for it. Maybe it’s just because I went in with low expectations but the writing felt very sharp and intelligent. It was a lot of fun and definitely above average.

Wonderful time watching this one.  It is easy to see why Guy Ritchie doesn't churn them out too often.  His style is unique and brilliantly thought out.  There were several complaints by moviegoers about this movie but honestly I had a great time keeping up and keeping track of the antics, twists and turns.  But to be fair I am a big Guy Ritchie Fan.  

Many people want to see Snatch, Lock/Stock and Sherlock Holmes redone over and over but each of his films are in many ways distinctly their own.  In fact, SyFy has had King Arthur on high rotation and I have watched it a few times this past month. I liked it when I saw it in the theater years ago and I liked it even more now because I was able to pick up nuances that are all Ritchie.  

In The Gentlemen, YES there is the one over used "C" word.  YES it can be tricky to keep up... But that is just it.. Keep up!  "There is truly only one rule in this jungle. When the lion's hungry... He eats."  The actors literally eat up each and every scene.  Even the scene where many viewers complained were too slow or too confusing. It just takes us coming out of our comfort zone to pay attention to what is going on, the back drops, the colors, the clothing, the slickness, the messiness the perfectness of it all to easily find yourself enjoying what is going on.

Mathew McConaughey is like a large Burmese Python.  Slowly moving through just about every scene he is in.  Don't be fooled. He is the sun the entire cast orbits around.  It is because we are not sure when or how he might strike and that keeps our eyes on him.  People complain about the Lincoln Car ads and maybe they are cheesy but heck this guy got arrested in his 20's for playing the bongo drums naked while high.  Was probably considered the least likely of all actors to process through a career but he has come a long way and I can appreciate him for that.

Charlie Hunnam is nattily dressed gold and McConaughey's right hand man who maybe doesn't always get it right but he cleans up after himself so he NEVER gets it wrong. Maybe his is Ritchie's good luck charm the way Jude Law was in a Holmes and King Arthur or maybe he is being paid back for King Arthur's poor showing but I loved not see him as Jax Teller from SoA.  I wish he did more movie work.  I think he is under appreciated for what he could do.

Colin Farrell is brilliant as a rehabilitator of young, strong lost souls and after so many bad movies it was wonderful to see him used in such a way to remind us of the fact that he is a solid actor and funny to boot.  

Henry Golding is (as always) gorgeous and seemingly a bit neurotic and too big for his britches but he is an antagonist and unfortunately (he doesn't catch the clue) a young male chimp who swings out a bit too far on a vine with no way to grad another for safety.

Michelle Dockery is making the most of her post Downton Abbey fame and while she is not seen overly much throughout the movie Ritchie has given her character heft and importance and one doesn't mess with this lioness.

As for Hugh Grant.  Yes his character is outsized and YES it is quite a turn for him to be so un Hugh Grant like but he is the one wheeze in this movie that I would have liked to have seen less of.  Maybe it was his annoying nasally whine or that he was on screen way too long but maybe less could have been more.  I am not sure though.  If less would have been more.

Jeremy Strong and Eddie Marsan positively drip with muck and slickness.  I have loved Marsan for all his work on Ray Donovan and know he is a versatile actor.  Jeremey Strong has been in so many movies I have seen and never paid attention to him.  I clearly did here and loved his role.

This is truly an ensemble cast wonderfully woven together to tell a story that may seem hard to understand but if you can get your frame of mind to understand that it is a Guy Ritchie movie and he spins a yarn like no one else you will have a solid and absolutely fun ride with these gentlemen.  Alright, alright, alright.

My sole qualm is that I found the screenplay and general plot unfolding to be slightly overdone. I think the change in timeline was necessary for the films full effect, but it seemed like it tried too hard to go back and forth and narrate and add asides, that it just became a little distracting. All in all, great performance, unique story, and an interesting perspective on manhood, business, the measure of success, and plain old style.

I'm a big fan of Guy Ritchie. This is a return to form resembling his early work. It's not as intense or action packed as those early offerings, but that's ok. Neither am I. I also noticed the cast matured in age & mellowed: The same way a college student keg stands their alcohol compared to the way an adult sips a tumbler of something aged to perfection. I liked the way the shots were framed and the subtle touches. For instance, in one scene a main character tells some kids to "sit". He repeats it with the hand signal you give to a dog. In the background of the kids is a framed picture of a dog. It made me smile. There's more of this through out the movie. I wanted this to be a 5 star movie for me, but the slow pace held it back. I think if they make this into a series of movies with these characters, I may come to appreciate more as an introduction to this world. But for now, it's a respectable 4 stars.

The Guy has returned with his trademark films and with such cast this movie rivals with Snatch (maybe not all the way but still). Some will say that it is still far cry from his early works but the point is to go forward not being still and in this movie is step forward for The Guy.

Awesome story, love the gangster crime movies like this from Guy Ritchie. Would 10/10 recommend it. The way the story is told is awesome as well. This might even be better than Snatch to some but I haven’t made my mind up about that yet.  Just an awesome, and entertaining movie.

What a mess, feels more like a Guy Ritchie rip-off. Extremely pretentious, the only things that work in this movie are the cast (not all of them) and the humor (not all of it), and none of that is enough to overcome the poorly conceived story structure in this lazy throwaway gangster script. I couldn't stand Hugh Grant in this movie his overacting in this just did not work for and he unfortunately is our unreliable narrator, he made it a painful movie to sit through but other other actors in the cast are excellent like Henry Golding, he's playing a very over the top gangster but we have so much fun watching. Eddie Marsden is also a blast in this movie. The Gentleman unfortunately is not one of Guy Ritchies best (although it is extremely well made), hopefully his next gangster film (we know he's never going to stop making these) is a lot better. 5.5/10

"The American Lion in the English Jungle"

	Guy Ritchie returns to both the writing and directing chair to craft an exciting action-filled comedy that only he and he alone could create. "The Gentlemen" stars a wide array of talent that perfectly bring Ritchie's patented expressive dialogue to life with every word they utter. The excitement in this film is not solely found in the action and gunshots that were heavily marketed but is instead felt within the elaborate narrative that keeps at a steady pace, along with the eccentric characters that help shepherd it along. Ritchie's style bleeds throughout this film's core from the very opening title credits, to the final cut to black; all of his standard trademarks are here which some may find tiresome, while others will find great enjoyment out of. Nevertheless, it should go without saying that with Ritchie in the driver's seat "The Gentlemen" is an immensely entertaining film that will keep audiences engaged in its wonderful world of formalized chaos.
	"The Gentlemen" centers around the suave Mickey Pearson (Matthew McConaughey), a kingpin that reigns over his established marijuana empire as he navigates throughout London attempting to remain on top, despite the many adversarial forces he faces along the way (But it is far more complex than that). A private investigator known only as Fletcher (Hugh Grant) is hired by Big Dave (Eddie Marsan), an editor for the Daily Print tabloid with the strict assignment of investigating Pearson's personal ties to a royal named Lord Pressfield (Samuel West). During the course of his investigation, Fletcher uncovers several secrets shrouded in mystery and deception. It is realized, that Pearson is fully intent on selling his business to the American billionaire,  Matthew Berger (Jeremy Strong) for a grand sum of $400 million. However, at the exact same time, a young Chinese crime boss named, Dry Eye (Henry Golding) is looking to relieve Pearson of the stress by outright buying the entire establishment. When Pearson refuses, he and his wife Rosalind Pearson (Michelle Dockery) along with his right-hand man Raymond (Charlie Hunnam) are thrust into a world of chaos where they are the primary targets everyone is aimed at. Having said that, it should be noted that the first two-thirds of the film are framed within a late-night conversation Fletcher invites Raymond to, with regards to his findings. Fletcher fully intends on selling his discoveries to Raymond in exchange for £20 million or he will go to print, a simple blackmail technique.
	Ritchie provides an exhilarating screenplay that keeps audiences glued to their seats guessing where it will go next and just when you think you've figured it out, the film takes a complete detour of absurdity that most would fail in their attempts  The film rarely stops to take a break which on paper may seem like a real flaw; but for "The Gentlemen" it is not. The narrative is told by the character of Fletcher and it feels extremely meta, so much so that a poster of one of Ritchie's previous projects can be spotted for keen eyes. This type of narrative structure is a technique that some may find distracting and unfocused, but I personally find it to be brilliant. After the beautiful opening credits, we are instantly thrown into a shocking moment that immediately grabs your attention like a salacious headline; it is hard to forget. With this inciting moment now lodged in our brains, the audience becomes hyper-focused as they watch in awe eagerly waiting for that fatal moment to come back; and when it finally does, it is just as shocking as it was when we first witnessed it. Although this is a method used by many writers and directors, Ritchie pulls it off in a way that does not entirely spoil the film from the offset. With the film's events unfolding through Fletcher's recounting of the situations, as an actual written screenplay titled, "Bush" you cannot help but be fully captivated. The constant callbacks to past incidents and shifts of perspective all add to create a story that is one of the most entertaining ones of the year.
	"The Gentlemen" as I expressed earlier, is a film constructed by an auteur that relishes in a flashy, yet extravagant style that only he could design. From a very entry-level observation, the first thing that will catch anyone's attention are the elaborate and debonair outfits everyone on the cast, dons. Regardless of whether it is a fresh tapered suit, a loose-fitting jacket, or a bold tracksuit, every character showcased on-screen displays a level of sophistication only Guy Ritchie could pull off. Every shoe, every top, every pair of glasses; every single article of clothing appears to have been hand-picked as a means of painting each individual cast member as a figure you will not soon forget. Surprisingly, this quality is not exclusive to only the main cast as many of the extras also have a unique visual flavor that brings more life into every moment. When the film travels from scene to scene, the characters look fantastic, but so is the dialogue they are speaking. Ritchie's use of language is rather impressive as none of his characters are presented as shallow one-trick ponies. Every line of dialogue is pointed with a purpose that perfectly sets the stakes for every scene as all of the actors and actresses are constantly vying to dominate the verbal battles they find themselves in. With metaphors and jokes littered all throughout, it is hard to not find all of the English accents just a bit endearing. Unfortunately, on the flip side, because of how animated the characters and their words can be at times, they will occasionally slip into the territory of a cartoonish caricature of themselves. It is not distinctively a fault of the film that ruins it by any means, but it can be a bit overwhelming from time to time (A sentiment that is true for the entirety of the film).
	"The Gentlemen" is a blast of a film that explodes with character and features a fabulous cast that all bring their best. From the costumes and sets to the characters and their dialogue, Ritchie's fingerprints are all over this film and it appears as though he is playing in a wheelhouse where he feels the most comfortable. Now of course, if you are not a fan of Guy Ritchie's films or his overabundant style, then "The Gentlemen" may not be your cup of tea. However, the story and visual flair used to present it, flows throughout every frame and is certainly something that will entertain from beginning to end. Truly the first must-watch of 2020.

Final Verdict - B-

After the awful live action Aladdin remake, Guy Ritchie has returned to his comfort zone with another gangster flick. The trailers looked entertaining, this film is populated with a terrific cast, and after seeing the film, I left satisfied with what I saw.

Matthew McConaughey is relentless in this movie and the best I have seen him in a long time. His character was awesome, smooth, and just flat out likable. Every performance in this movie was terrific and totally fit the tone that this movie was going for. There were some very funny sequences and a lot of fun to be had throughout most of the run-time. That being said, there isn't a lot of action like some critics are saying. Like there is action in the movie, but it's not "action packed". It was a fun time to be had with a pretty good story once everything comes together. Some of the side characters I thought were going to get annoying at first but they quickly became important to the story and likable. Also, the opening title sequence was honestly fun to look at and the music choice enhanced the scene greatly. For a January that's been a mixed bag for movies, it was pleasant to sit through a movie like this and Bad Boys 3. However I do have some problems with the film.

Now I mentioned that there is a good story in this film and that's totally true, but the way its told was rather confusing at first. Even though the story comes through in the end, it took awhile for me to understand the way this film was telling its story. It began like it was a part of a movie script, but the events were also happening. Also, as good as some acting was for these characters, it doesn't change the fact that most of them were underwritten. Also, one of the villains was very annoying and I didn't really buy him as a villain. 

This movie was a fun time at the movies and a perfectly enjoyable flick especially considering the time in which it came out in being January. Nothing game changing, but Guy Ritchie is definitely in his comfort zone when working on this genre. Hopefully he never does anything like Aladdin again...jokes aside, I'm going to give The Gentlemen, a B

Though some have found "The Gentlemen" to be a showcase of writer/director Guy Ritchie at his most entry level, it just so happens to be exactly what this reviewer was asking for all along. As someone who's clung so unabashedly to the notion that his "Sherlock Holmes" films are the best things he's ever done, I was wary of this return to the early days for Ritchie. I don't particularly dislike movies like "Lock, Stock," "Snatch" or "RocknRolla." I just find them a bit too showy and brash for my tastes. However, it seems the skills accrued via those jaunts through studio-dom have perhaps melded with the indie sensibilities that were already so present within the man. And the movie's all better for it. Yes, "The Gentlemen" is still undeniably Ritchie, but with just the right amount of focus, tact and accessibility to make even the most fervent of Ritchie-deniers leave the theater feeling satisfied. As shocked as I am to say this, I have to admit - I honestly think this is my favorite of the "proper" Guy Ritchie gangster flicks.

If you don't want to see a gritty, violent and swearing sensation of a movie, then obviously this movie is not for you. I loved this movie, it's been one of the best movies so far this year, and overall will possibly make my top 10 or 15 of 2020. Why? Because this movie is engaging, it drives a fast pace story that is changing and taking new turns as each scene begins. There are some interesting and creative techniques used in this movie that don't belong in a "British Mafia Drama," such as that surprising gang music video. This movie surprised me, and I hope it will surprise you. As a young aspiring filmmaker myself, with a few gangster features under my belt, this film gave me callbacks to the drive, ambition, vision and thrill I had when I wrote my own mafia trilogy. I went into this movie expecting it to be bloody decent, because apparently not too many critics appreciated it. It blew me away, and I was very pleased. I don't disagree with professional critics that much, there's only a handful of movies that have been the case. "The Gentlemen" is a gritty Guy Ritchie movie, and deserves more appreciation than what some are giving it. Not the best gangster flic out there, but it sure is a damn good one.

"You really can't unsee it once you've seen it." 

Guy Ritchie returns to his gangster roots in the underbelly of jolly good England. It's crazy to think that this is the same guy who brought us last years ‘Aladdin.' But this time Ritchie isn't on a leash.

I honestly didn't expect to enjoy ‘The Gentleman' as much as I did. A little muddle and sometimes confusing to follow, but the movie has a certain sharpness to it that kept me interested throughout. It's more in vein with ‘Lock Shock' and ‘Snatch'. Ritchie has made a successful career being influenced by the work of Quentin Tarantino, hence his given title "British Tarantino". 

The cast are all having an absolute blast with the material and I can tell everyone wants to be there. 

Hugh Grant is my personal favorite out of the cast and it's great to see his enthusiasm in acting again. He plays Fletcher, a gay detective who documents the events in the story into a screenplay he's writing, so in a way it's told from his perspective. While debatable if everything in the movie was made up or not, cause "every movie needs a bit of action". The thing I love about Grants performance is that he isn't playing "typical Hugh Grant", but an actual character. Although I thought the running gag of him being openly gay and constantly makes flirty hints towards other male characters got old and awkward after awhile. A joke that out stay's it's welcome...kinda like Fletcher.

I'm not a big fan of Charlie Hunnam as an actor, as I usually find him bland in everything I've seen him so far. However I thought Hunnam delivered a solid performance in this movie and might be his best. He plays Ray, Mickey's (McConaughey) right hand man who is professional when it comes to business despite the countless idiots in his path. Imagine Russell Bufalino from ‘The Irishman', but more physical and incredibly British. His comedic timing was pretty good as well that maybe if you give him the right material and character, he's a better actor than I thought.

Colin Farrell was terrific as Coach and my second favorite out of the cast. He's ridiculously cool and shows who's boss, but also display's some comedic chops. Matthew McConaughey was chilled as Mickey, who is the weed Lord of England that likes things in green, which is money and marijuana. Out of all the colorful characters in the movie, I thought Mickey was the least interesting if I have to be honest. Either because of McConaughey's chilled nature or the less exciting material given to his character. 

The style and overall tone of the movie made the whole experience so fun to watch. Everything about the movie is quick. The dialogue is snappy and there's plenty of clever banter between characters. It's incredibly clear that Guy Richie loves cinema whenever he's not held back like some of his previous projects and gets to freely express his passion behind the craft. 

The humor and jokes ain't for the faint of heart, but luckily I'm not that soft. Some of jokes didn't quite land the mark and often times left me puzzled in terms of waiting for the punchline. 

Overall rating: A disjointed, but entertaining movie. Misleading title though. There's plenty of man, but not so much on gentle.

'The Gentlemen' (2020)
Guy Ritchie returns to the crime genre and what a solid return I must say. 'The Gentlemen' is a witty and fun ride, packed to the brim with great dialogue and great action. Each of the cast is mostly great in the film, especially Charlie Hunnam, Hugh Grant, and Matthew McConaughey. It's nice to finally see McConaughey in a good movie again after somewhat of a lull in his career in my opinion. Collin Farrell is great of course, although definitely seems to have less of a screen time than the prior three I had mentioned. I should also say that this is a very fast-paced film for the most part. It's one you certainly can't doze or space off during otherwise you may end up completely lost. The cinematography and screenplay overall is good, although the best aspect I believe is the script, extremely well-written, rich, smart, and witty dialogue throughout. If I were to pinpoint any criticisms, I suppose some of it would come down to the pacing as I mentioned before. Usually it's good, however it seems as though you either hit a slight lull here and there, or rather it's just bursting from scene to scene. The editing is also a peculiar case, in that it's normally good however will get very eccentric from time to time. Some of the acting was a bit iffy for me at times, mainly from Henry Golding, Jeremy Strong, and maybe a few lesser supporting characters, although at this point I think I'm nitpicking... This is the slick new crime action comedy from Guy Richie, and if you like his other films you'll probably like this one, too. It's a funny and suave take on the British criminal underground scene with a pert editing style that keeps the pace upbeat and moving. Unlike many of his other films, however, this one starts off with a lot of exposition, but once it finds its footing it does not disappoint. The actors all seem to be having a blast and the ending wraps everything up so neatly that it's hard to find fault with the slower beginning. It's great to see Guy Richie back doing the modern gangster films he does best.

Closest comparison: It's like The Godfather by way of Baby Driver, but without the musical choreography.

Tone: Action Comedy

've been hoping, wishing, praying for Guy Ritchie to return back to his screwball Cockney crime pictures of his splashy beginning, but the further and further I get from 2001's Snatch, the more I think it's a luxuriously madcap exception. The Gentlemen is a closer return to form than 2008's RocknRolla, but it's still a long way off from early Ritchie. The recognizable elements are there, from the convoluted story with twists and turns, the non-linear storytelling lapping and overlapping itself, the comical brushes with sudden violence, the colorful array of criminal characters, and a sense of style that seems all over the place. We follow Matthew McConaughey as a marijuana titan looking to get out of the business, though there are threats old, new, and "just business" that are trying to take his empire from him before his exit. The biggest problem with The Gentlemen is how clever it feels like it needs to be and how few characters there are to find interesting. Snatch, by contrast, forever contrast, was practically a Dick Tracy rogues gallery of all its memorable and unpredictable characters. These feel pretty rote, even our heroes, and the minority characters get even shorter shrift. The plot is also more complicated than it needs to be with an extended meta-textual layer of a lecherous Hugh Grant tabloid journalist pitching the story like it was a movie (irony: it is a movie!). It took maybe 45 minutes before I felt like the story was finally picking up momentum and stakes, and by the end, it felt like Ritchie was just extending his story with another twist and wrap-up, and then another twist and wrap-up, like the outer edges of the movie cannot be contained and somehow it's still even going. It's like Ritchie doesn't know when to walk away from his own party. Because of these things the pacing is wonky and there are more than a few tedious stretches. Colin Farrell has some amusing moments but should have been the main character as a boxing trainer who takes a shine to try and reform local hoodlums. McConaughey's character is too boring and always wins too easily, which makes him more boring. The Gentlemen is a C-level rendition of Ritchie's best material, and Snatch only shines even brighter with each new miss.

Nate's Grade: C+

Look, you know whether or not you're the audience for this. If you liked Snatch and Lock, Stock and Rock n Rolla (or god help you, Revolver), then The Gentlemen will go down smooth like a fine scotch. Ritchie effortlessly weaves his trademark twisted storylines together in clever and hilarious ways — with solid performances throughout. I have to call out Hugh Grant here, who kinda steals the movie away from his other, more "tough guy" counterparts. Some of the English slang sounds a bit weird coming out of McConaughey's voice, but he mostly pulls off his fierce kingpin character with appropriate venom. See this one with boys.

Guy Ritchie delivers a thoroughly delightful and devilishly hilarious British comical thriller. Matthew McConaughey, Charlie Hunnam and Hugh Grant are amond the standouts but supporting actors Colin Farrell, Henry Golding and Jeremy Strong are all critical to the plot and to making the film shine with clever brilliance. Also, not to be forgotten is the mischievous Michelle Dockery, who's Rosalind complements McConaughey's Mickey to perfection. Also I love when the British call marijuana "bush" or  "skunk" but there's also something very satisfying about Matthew McConaughey saying the words "Sweet Mary Jane."

"The Gentlemen" is an okay movie that I felt had the potential to be great. The movie boasts a strong cast, a unique style, but ultimately an average story. I think this movie is a perfect example of style over substance, which is not always a bad thing for a Guy Ritchie movie. I've liked his style in the past and I liked it in this movie. The story drags heavily in the middle sections and doesn't always have a smooth flow. It moves quickly but that doesn't mean its always interesting. Overall, the actors did a fine job and the movie is very stylish, but I can't see myself watching it again, and can certainly think of other Guy Ritchie films I like a lot more.

I like to think of The Gentlemen as a far less tame version of The Kingsman. While thematically different, Guy Ritchie captures the essence of what made The Kingsman films so enjoyable while seemingly settling in to his own style of story telling that felt fresh and a welcome change from many of the films churned out by many big-name production companies in recent times.
Does it reinvent the wheel as films go? Goodness no.
However, Ritchie excels at bringing a fantastic, somewhat non-linear, and utterly hilarious film to our cinema screens and deserves nothing less than the highest praise.

A classic dose of Guy Ritchie filmmaking, "The Gentlemen" is a wonderful exhibit of the power of storytelling. An all-star cast provides life to a wildly entertaining set of gangsters and thugs, each as distinct and memorable as the last, an impressive feat as they all are simultaneously playing the same type of character. While Ritchie's finesse for the crime-caper narrative seems to take a play-it-safe mentality, The Gentlemen is never boring, even if it is missing a "British" Brad Pitt asking if you like dags, "Dags?...Oh yea, I like dogs."

Classic Guy Ritchie style. Did not disappoint!!  Great, creative storytelling and of course memorable, colorful characters. Great performance not only by Mcconaughey, but the entire cast...yes, even Hugh Grant, putting forth a character performance well balanced between class and sleaze.  If you're a fan of Ritchie's work, you're gonna love this movie.  Great fun and highly entertaining!!

I highly recommend you take a look at this one.

This is a fantastic movie! Lots of action and humor both, many twists in the plot, an amazing script ripe with well written and executed dialogue, the characterization was brilliant. I cannot recommend this movie enough. I would pay to see this movie in the the theatre a second time!

This film is getting a lot of great reviews so I checked it out. I like all the older Guy Richie stuff so this should be the same. The acting, cinematography and pace of the film was great. By the ending of the film it felt like they tried to cram and make as many twist as possible.

Loved the action. Loved the humor. Great writing. Loved seeing Hugh Grant in that seedy, grungy role! Glad Guy Ritchie gave us another of his movies.

I have been waiting to be able to review this terrific movie for a month now (it started in Australia in december) to question what the hell movie critics go to the cinema for! 
If (like me) you go to the cinema to be entertained and not lectured, then this is the film for you- I can't remember the last time I enjoyed a visit to the cinema as much as this.

The Gentlemen is purely and simply a great romp of a film and exactly the sort of movie Guy Ritchie excels at- violent, gritty, funny. If you enjoyed Lock, Stock and And Two Smoking Barrels and Snatch, then you will LOVE The Gentlemen.

GO SEE IT!!!!!!

No where near the calibre of Snatch, or even LS&TSB, The Gentlemen delivers a movie that is perhaps now 'too formulaic' from Guy Ritchie, who appears to rely too heavily on his past success in 'gritty but stylish UK crime drama-comedy' he helped define.

Mathew McCon. is a weed crime lord of an empire that is pure ridiculous in the extreme and very unbelievable as a premise.  He wants to sell his empire and chaos ensues.  Mathew is mis-cast and phones in a dreary boring performance.

The standout performance that saves this film for complete ruin is by Hugh Grant, who will likely get an oscar nod for his supporting role as a very kinky sleezy UK tabloid paparazzi cameraman.

Colin Farrell turns in an 'ok' role which is very similar to the Brad Pitt role in Snatch, so much so you groan at it.

The first half of this movie is soooo boring that I contemplated taking a nice stroll to the loo, which is 3 floors down in the basement in the crap theatre I was in.  It's two guys sitting and one guy telling a story.  Often about another guy sitting, talking.

Perhaps most disturbing about this movie is that it is horrifically tone-deaf, with gratuitous racism towards jews in particular, as well as stereotyping horrors for asians, and the one token woman in the movie is subjected to a near-rape scene with almost zero fight back from her (after she is disarmed) I found it unpleasant.

Worth a rental to see Hugh do a fantastic sleeze character.  Not good for much else.
Typical Guy Richie Twists and turns. Lot of action. A very good January movie
A solid, Ritchie caper which doesn't take itself too seriously, has some fine performances and has enough twists and turns to keep you guessing to the end. Bosh, geezer, sorted!

I really loved this and stylish story filled sultry dialogue. All actors are pumping on all cylinders. An even stew with a mixture of fun, crime, betrayal and violence. Its dialogue heavy so be prepared. It flows nicely at the hands of Hugh Grant as a sleazy journalist as he serves as sort of a narrator.

Drug kingpin, Mickey, played viciously by Matthew McConaughey, wants to sell his empire and what follows is a domino effect of events. Keeping it spoiler free.

Guy Ritchie does a fantastic job of telling a story. Matthew M. is so cool,calm and collected you actually start to forget he is even supposed to be a drug dealer. All the actors did a great job and the wordplay was on point. I thoroughly enjoyed this feature,hope everyone else does too.
awesome movie love the movie format

MARCs MOVIE REVIEW:
The Gentlemen 


Starring Matthew McConaughey, Hugh Grant and a great cast this is a real old fashioned movie and one to enjoy. 

It has a Tarantino quality but is more grounded. It was made by people who understand that movies need to entertain and who found a way to blend whimsy as in The Mask with the skillful cuts of Pulp Fiction and a storyline that borrows from Connery era Bond films. 

Thats not to say the screenplay wasnt a captivating tale, or the acting mediocre. Neither could be further from the truth. 

The story is Marvel-esque and the acting carries you comfortably into a suspension of disbelief by a twisty turny route through British Aristocracy and the brutality of the criminal mind. 

With Downton Abbeys Michelle Dockery, Colin Farrell, Henry Golding and British star Charlie Hunnam you feel as if the biggest among young stars wanted to do this movie and collaborated at the top of their game. 

All 5 thumbs up for this flick.

Director Guy Ritchie (Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels (1998), Snatch (2000), Sherlock Holmes (2009), Aladdin (2019)) has a sort of style to his movies that you either like, or don't like. For the most part I enjoy his movies especially the one's focused on the whole genre of 'gangster comedies.' He seems to be the best in these kind of films and The Gentlemen did not disappoint. The movie is about a marijuana distributor named Mickey Pearson (Matthew McConaughey) who is trying to sell his business off and retire. His potential buyer Matthew Berger (Jeremy Strong) has some doubts about the business after some snags in the deal happen involving a hot headed young gangster named Dry Eye (Henry Golding). The movie is told in a series of flashbacks by an investigative journalist named Fletcher (Hugh Grant) who is talking to Mickey's right hand man Ray (Charlie Hunnam) and during this time we aw the viewer figure out that there's much more going on than it seems. The movie also stars Colin Farrell as Coach. I really enjoyed this one. It has a very complex plot where it takes you on a ride going back and forth with the story, so it's imperative to pay attention. It's very much like Ritchie's other gangster comedies where they don't really let you stop to think much and you have to go with it. The film has some very funny moments here and overall I enjoyed how it ended. I will say some people may be put off by the overall story as it sometimes kind of overcomplicates itself for the sake of moving the plot, but it didn't bother me much. This is a solid film and I highly recommend checking it out!

So I'm probably one of the few, but I had never seen a Guy Ritchie film before this movie besides Sherlock Holmes. And I am glad to say, as a fan of crime movies, this movie did not disappoint. I think that the most appealing part of this movie are the characters, at least for me. Specifically, McConaughey, Grant, and Farrell were the highlight performances for me. McConaughey was definitely the centerpiece of the film, shining as the villainous but gentlemen-like protagonist. Grant brought the charisma and the slight over the top performance this film needed. Farrell was a surprise because he had a lot heart as well as good comic relief. Charlie Hunnam also did great as Ray and Henry Golding as Dry Eye. I downgrade this film a little because it is very excessive in its language use and it also plays out a little predictably at some parts. It also has some slight pacing issues as well as a surprisingly weaker Jeremy Strong performance.  However, this is a great intro to Guy Ritchie's crime movies for me and I enjoyed it very much.

The Gentlemen is a refreshing look at the criminal world in the frame of big business.  Taking a step away from the traditional portrayals of organized crime the movie rocks amazing performances from the entire cast. The refreshing and twisting plot is fantastic and has quite a few commentary's on society.  While others tear down Matthew McConaughey's portrayal as flat but in reality he portrays a cold, cold sociopath who only becomes truly bothered by one thing... someone messing with his wife. His wife played by Michelle Dockery is a fantastic female character.  She is her own woman and NOT about to take crap from her husband or anyone else.  Dockery plays her perfectly.  Charlie Hunnam shines as a devoted and calm consigliere with his own quirks and ability to quickly adapt. Colin Farrell is a crazy nutball who finds himself in some unique positions due to the boys he trains. Henry Golding plays a hungry character that might be felt to be a bit stereotypical but fits in perfectly with this cast. Finally Hugh Grant blows everyone away by portraying the slimiest of slimiest characters ever.  Spending the money to see his performance so different from any others is well worth the money.  Overall, this is a great movie and far more refreshing than any other recent crime drama's from the likes of Martin Scorsese who seem to have excellent actors playing cookie cutter characters.
